title: How many deaths attributed to COVID-19 will have been reported by the World Health Organization (WHO) for Spain as of 1 May 2020?
possible_answers: More than 9,000 but less than 12,000 deaths
preds: Spain has reported a further 517 people who tested positive for covid-19 have died taking the total number of deaths in the country to 17,489 as well as 3,477 new cases of the virus taking the total to 169,496- Sky News.

Spain TC 157022 NC 4576 Total Deaths = 15843   New Deaths  605
https://www.who.int/docs/default-source/coronaviruse/situation-reports/20200411-sitrep-82-covid-19.pdf?sfvrsn=74a5d15_2
As of 9 April 2020, 21:00 hours, Spain has surpassed 15,000 with a total of 15,843 and counting.

Creo que de acá al 1 de mayo según los datos registrados por España, habrán entre 9 y 12 mil muertos más con una probabilidad de 75%. Esto utilizando los datos totales del país y su evolución a medida que pasa el tiempo. Tras 27 días de confinamiento, van al rededor de 16000 muertos en dicho país.  Esta predicción se basa en términos ambientales y sanitarios de la región en la que se encuentra el país. Los últimos días las cifras de muertos en dicho país han disminuido de pasar de cerca de 900 muertos diarios en su peak a 605 el día recién pasado. Esta baja lleva ya algunos días, por lo que algunas predicciones se pueden hacer. Considerando que en Europa el invierno ya esta alejandose y los climas de acá al 1 de mayo comenzaran a ser bastante más cálidos, dan para pensar que estos contagios disminuirán, ya que las defensas de las personas vuelven a subir disminuyendo resfrios e infecciones contagiosas. Es por el época del año que ocurrió todo en Europa una de las razones de esta explosividad de contagios, ya que los agarró en pleno invierno, época más critica para enfermedades pulmonares sobre todo para adultos mayores.  Tras ver los datos, se puede ver que los muertos por día han ido bajando. Esto se relación en gran medida con el clima y el sin fin  de medidas que se han ido adoptando en términos de santifización, trabajos, escuelas, etc. Es por esto que ya con la gente preparada y al tanto del tema, que predigo que en los próximos 21 días habrán entre 9 y 12 mil muertos más, con un promedio de entre 450 a 600 muertos diarios. A la fecha se va con un promedio de casi 700 muertos diarios pero considerando las primeras semanas donde el virus recién brotaba y la cifra de muertos era mucho menor.  Esto generará un tipo de campana de gauss, haciendo que a medida que nos acercamos al verano Europeo los contagios comiencen a bajar. 25% restante de la predicción es producto de lo impredecible del virus y su mutación, ya que nadie sabe como se puede seguir comportando. Existe la opción de que ocurra lo de Japón, donde luego de mejoras gigantes, se tuvo que volver al estado de emergencia. Lo mismo podría ocurrir en cualquier otro pais.  Es por estas razones que mi predicción de España es que tenderá a ir a la baja en cantidad de muertos diarios, ya que su peak más alto esta siendo dejado atrás. No significa que esta pandemia se acabe en este país, ya que falta la etapa de baja, luego la de manutención y un buen  tiempo esperando si existe o no un re brote de la pandemia.
Looking at the doubling rate at this point, it seems likely we'll hit over 15,000 deaths.

Sadly, it is certain to go well over 15k by the end of Apr
(having total 13,798 and daily 743 as of Apr.9).
Currently (8/4) Worldometers is reporting the total deaths in Spain to Covid-19 as 14,555. It should pass 15,000 either tomorrow or the day after.
More than 15,000 close to a sure thing unfortunately.
At current there are 13K reported cases. It is unlikely that their current measures will create the kind of reduction where any other option is possible.

As at 03.04.2020 11,744 death rising. Slight decrease of rate of newly reported cases over the last 3 days, but still increasing. Death rate is around 10%. Predicting  probably 25000 to 30000 deaths in Spain at 1st May.

The S-curve for deaths seems to have an inflection point of about 7100 for today, to be compare to  6730, 6290, 5970, 5800, 5500, 5350, 5200, 5550 for yesterday, the day before yesterday, etc. So back to my first prediction and time to pass to another question.
I almost feel like I am cheating entering this forecast when the death toll is already so high and still rising quickly.   Maybe we will get lucky, and someone will find a cure.
3 min, already at 11500, 10% death rate with 7.5k new cases each day so medical system will still be overwhelmed
Based on the last report of 760 deaths in the past 24 hours

WorldOMeter says 10935 today April 3 and the number today down to 537 new deaths. 27 days left. You would only need to average about 149 a day to reach 15000. They might be starting on the downhill side of the curve but that is a month to six weeks.

The S-curve for deaths seems to have an inflection point of about  6730 for today, to be compare to 6290, 5970, 5800, 5500, 5350, 5200, 5550 for yesterday, the day before yesterday, etc. Thus reduce 12-15K bucket probability.
Deaths will more than double today's total of 10,000+
Cov19 mortality in Spain is very high and there are still many people to develop the virus and therefore the number of deaths will increase

As of my writing this (April 2nd), the death toll in Spain due to coronavirus is 10,348. Spain's first death occurred on March 3rd, 30 days ago. If we extrapolate an exponential function from this to find the death rate and predict death counts for future days, using f(x) = a(b)^x, we get 10,348 = 1(b)^30, which simplifies to a death rate of the 30th root of 10,348, which is 36%. If we are optimistic and assume that Spain's lockdown will cut transmission and thus death rates by 50%, giving us a death rate of 18% going forward, and want to find the number of deaths on May 1st, which is 31 days from now, we can use the expression 10,348(1.18)^31 to come to a total number of 1,750,647 deaths. Of course there are many other factors that will lower the death count such as the building of new hospitals, increased efficiency of social distancing among the population, an increased medical supply, etc, one can be 100% confident any measures could be enacted this late in the timeline to reduce that death count below 15,000.
https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/country/spain/.

Deaths at a rate of more than 700 per day, though this rate will likely drop.  Total deaths in 28 days will likely be more than 10,003 + 700 x 5 + 600 x 5 + 500 x 5 + 300 x 13 = 22,903.

The S-curve for deaths seems to have an inflection point of about 6290 for today, to be compare to 5970, 5800, 5500, 5350, 5200, 5550 for yesterday, the day before yesterday, etc. Thus reduce 12-15K bucket probability.
Spain roughly follows Italy by 5 days. 15000 should be reached in a 8 days assuming slightly declining growth rate, by end of April very unlikely that number has not been reached.

It seems like the peak has been reached and there will be a downturn in the next few days.
Deaths and new confirmed cases lag decisions like complete lockdown by a few weeks so everything points to a downturn.
Decent chance that the number might be around 16k -18k by May.
9k reported already.  Approximately 800 new deaths daily.
At the current rate, we would hit 15,000 in 7 days. Only a new treatment or a change in accounting could impact the results
already at 10 thousand. I project 19000 by May 1st

The current doubling time in Spain is 7 days for deaths. However it looks like that the infected cases have reached its peak on 29 March.
Assume that is the case, my logical model indicates 16k total deaths by 1 May.   This is much larger than the last basket.
Perhaps Spain will be leveling out in April.

The S-curve for deaths seems to have an inflection point of about 5970 for today, to be compare to 5800, 5500, 5350, 5200, 5550 for yesterday, the day before yesterday, etc. Even in China the number of deaths seemed to have stabilized above twice the mark of the inflection point (maybe about 2.5 times, but this depends on where you locate the inflection point owing to the roughness of data). Thus I increase the probabilities in the higher bucket.
Spain is still on the increase. March 31=7340 fatalities

I will lower the probabilities on the basis that the inflection point of the S-curve is about 6K, giving a plateau of between 12-18K. Yet from previous questions about the coronavirus, S-curves have systematically under predicted the final outcome of a question. Basically the same as my previous forecast [1], but giving more weight to the S-curve argument. [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/1004125

Based on total cases estimate of 180-210K, I'm assuming a gradual reduction in fatality rate after the next two weeks, once the number of daily cases has dropped and additional aid has been added. Taking into account a slight lag and the stretched resources I think the fatality rate will still be high, and get a figure between 12,000 and 16,000 total.

Surpassing 6k, according to SitRep 70. A simple model of a flat daily average mortality rate (which is deceptive and likely wrong but I'm using it for simplicity on the upswing,) would put us in the realm of 21k.
https://www.who.int/docs/default-source/coronaviruse/situation-reports/20200330-sitrep-70-covid-19.pdf?sfvrsn=7e0fe3f8_2

283 deaths per day put this over 15,000. The numbers are either growing or flat at about 800 per day currently. Deaths doubled in 6 days (current) Cases also doubled in 6 days, suggesting that the there are already confirmed enough cases to provide a doubling in deaths (to ~13,000)
Using Italy as a likely surrogate the deaths will rapidly spiral out of control.

Referencing Italy's CFR, which was 7.9% on 2020 Mar 18th, as Spain is on 2020 Mar 29th.  Italy's CFR is now >10%, 11 days later.  Suppose Spain follows same trajectory, and reach CFR 10% and stays there till May 1st.  From another question, I forecasted Spain would have 95% chance of having >180K confirmed cases by May 1st.  10% of this is 18K.  Hence forecasting 95% chance Spain will have >15K deaths by May 1st.
Note - as internet is iffy the next few days as my town deals with recovery from a spectacular F3 in  a pandemic and agency's fight for control - I'm making larger than normal adjustments. FYI

Who writes these questions? Can I suggest that you should pick some sort of reasonable centerpoint based on estimates from epidemiologists. Then make logarithmic buckets around that estimate on the up and down sides.
I am expecting this threshold to be crossed by April 10th.

Statista.com says about an 9% death rate. https://www.statista.com/statistics/1105914/coronavirus-death-rates-worldwide/
If there are about 180,000 cases on May 1 then 9%. Let’s say 10% since CNN article puts it higher. That is 18,000. 
WHO says 4858 on March 28. This chart says double every 2 1/2 days. https://twitter.com/justinwolfers/status/1244014016067964928?s=21
Way more than 18000

The mortality rate of covid-19 in Spain has been greater than 8%, and if it remains that way and there were 15,000 deaths, that would imply a total number of cases was around 150,000, but I think the total number of cases will exceed that, and so the number of deaths will also be greater.

Second approximation: about 6000 cases today, some comparisons: 1) Classical S-fit curve: a symmetric one suggests 11K deaths, an asymmetric one about 14K deaths. This is the optimistic view, yet when we applied that for the China cases (not deaths) we ended up consistently underestimating the actual final number of cases (first forecasters went to 50K, then to 70K), and this without taking into account that their data were doctored. 2) Comparison with the Chinese data: they peaked about 1200-1300 death, they reached about 2.5 times that quantity. The experience with Korea suggests a longer tail than the Chinese one. Spain has not clearly peaked yet, which means we should expect 15K+ at least. This is despite the doctoring. If we take Korea as an alternative comparison, we should get more than 15K. For the moment I will settle in {0, 0, 0, 5, 95} despite being on {0, 0, 0, 0, 100}, as I trust more the point of view 2)
Hopefully Spain's stringent methods will reduce fatalities soon.

I think the situation has improved in recent days. 5 Days ago the deaths were doubling every 2 days now it is more like every 2.5 days - and this is down from a peak of every 1.5 days 2 weeks ago. I am hoping the death rate will start to look more like Italy's in the next week and level off thereafter. I am going to say we are looking at around 15k deaths by the 1st of May. I'm hoping this is a little high but its still early days.
Up to 5812 today. +674 so far today.
5138 as of 28th March. Deaths are running at about 750 a day with some room to increase: wouldn't be surprised if we had at least a couple days of 1k deaths +.

The article does not mention time but I assume it is the total number of deaths per year. Past the question end date.  Spain already has over 5000 deaths. Currently doubling every 3-4 days. Lockdown protocol could move this curve toward the doubling every 7-10 day line.

Correction: currently number of deaths is approx 750 per day and likely to increase for the next couple of weeks at least towards, as the total number of cases is still increasing in the short term at least. At around 5,000 deaths already is seems very likely the total will sadly pass 15,000.

Based on an estimate of the total number of cases being well in excess of 200,000, and possibly double this number by the end of April, the number of deaths is sadly very likely to be greater than 15,000. Particularly if the heath system struggles with any surge in cases over the next few weeks. Number of deaths per day is approx 1,000 and  likely to increase for the next couple of weeks at least, lagging 2-3 wks behind the growth in total cases.

As of March 27 there are 4,934 deaths in Spain; deaths as a % of total cases is currently 7.7%.  Peak documented cases should be between 100,000 and 180,000; or 7700 and 13860 with a mean of 10780. I am hedging for the potential amelioration with improving treatments and decreasing percentage of deaths as testing rates increase and deaths as % of total cases decrease.
Need to redo calculations but somewhere between 13,000 and 18,000.

Anything less than 15,000 will be due to improved treatment ability

Comparing to South Korea. Their situation on 3 March was similar to Spain today, taking about their absolute growth for the weeks to follow, we should be at about 10000 cases in Spain by 1 May. SK was very strict in testing and especially isolating, so I consider that the bottom line. They got it under control early, which isn´t certain for Spain, so there is some potential upwards. On the other hand they are very strict now, so it could happen. Thats´s about 3rd and 4th bucket. If it got really out of control (and that can happen, because there are more cases of local spreading than in SK), it would easily go beyond 15000. Will have to adjust this to new numbers every few days.

15k is 3.7 times what Johns Hopkins is showing today (4,089). Spain is currently doubling every 4 days. That's 8 days to pass 15k, and 35 days until the deadline. With an average time from symptoms to death of 14 days, there are already enough people infected to reach 15k. https://gisanddata.maps.arcgis.com/apps/opsdashboard/index.html#/bda7594740fd40299423467b48e9ecf6
